content.description: Not a bad route at all. Feet on the slab hands in the crack or sometimes on the steeper wall. When Torie and I climbed it we removed some loose rock but be careful as it will likely exfoliate a little more. The gear was decent but did get a little thin in the middle so again, care must be taken. I personally don't think anyone had climbed it before us but this hill has lots of hidden history.
content.protection: trad gear to trees or lower off
content.location: This route follows the crack that runs between the slab and the steep wall and then heads up into the trees or cuts over to the top of Gritty gremlin.

content.description: The line of bolts on the left side of the wall, this offers cool moves to a dynamic crux. The rock is beautiful up top.

This was the first route I bolted at Russel. Start by working your way up the crack. Break left and head up onto the face. As you move up, make several tricky moves right to easier climbing to gain the anchors.
content.protection: 5 bolts to a 2 bolt pig tail anchor
content.location: Located on the slab to the right of the steep routes.

content.description: A good warmup for the wall, this is the right-most bolted route on the diamond. Climb up the crack (gear needed) until you can reach left and clip the first bolt. Move onto the face and climb past a protruding block and a face to the anchors.
content.protection: Finger to hand sized gear to the bolts to LO

content.description: Champagne Corolla is the class of the wall. Start in the crack (you can place a few cams in the crack, or just stick clip the high bolt). Remain in the crack until after the first bolt, then move left onto the steep wall at or near the second bolt. The rad moves keep coming--none too easy, none too hard, all the way to the anchors. This route was developed the day after Justin Townes Earle tragically passed, and naming this route after his song, Champagne Corolla, seemed a fitting tribute.
content.protection: Bolts to LO. Some cams for the start if you don't have a long stick clip.

content.description: The Diamond lies somewhat hidden below The Ruin. It's basically the perfect little sport cliff--tall but not too tall, steep but not too steep, and festooned with really cool holds on pretty orange rock. Expect routes 5.9-5.12, which is again, perfect.
